actions.text:
It sounds like your apartment needs repairs. First, tell us a little about who owns your apartment.

You can say:

NYCHA  

PRIVATE LANDLORD or

I'M NOT SURE
It looks like you live in public housing (aka NYCHA). To ask NYCHA directly for repairs, call the Customer Contact Center ("CCC") at 718-707-7771.
We know NYCHA does not always respond to tenants who need repairs. Would you like to hear more options for getting repairs?
You can say YES to learn more repairs or NO to learn more about other housing rights.

You selected private landlord!  Is your apartment rent-regulated*? 

You can say: YES, NO, or I DON'T KNOW

*Rent regulated includes rent-stabilized, rent controlled, project-based Section 8, HUD, Mitchell Lama
If you're ready to report your housing problems to the City, you can call 311.
The City should send an inspector from the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development ("HPD"). Do you want to learn more about an HPD inspection?

You can say: 

YES, to learn more about inspections or NO if you've already called 311 and want to explore other options.
While you can definitely use this TextBot to learn more about your right to get repairs today, you may want to speak with a lawyer before taking action.

Before we go on, do you want to learn about speaking to a free housing lawyer?  

You can say: YES or NO
It looks like you are a market rate tenant.
Retaliation is illegal but before taking action, you may want to speak to a lawyer.
Do you want to learn about legal resources in your neighborhood? Write YES to speak to a lawyer and NO if you feel ready to start learning about how to take action.
To write a letter of complaint to NYCHA that explains all your repair issues, you can use JustFix's Complaint Tool: https://app.justfix.nyc/en/loc.
JustFix will send this letter to NYCHA via certified mail at no cost to you.
We also understand that NYCHA does not always respond to letters from tenants. Do you want to learn about how to sue NYCHA for repairs?
You can say: YES to hear about how to sue NYCHA for repairs or NO to learn about other housing rights.
Based on our research, there's a good chance you live in rent stabilized housing.
But, if you're not sure, there are ways to explore further!

Do you want to learn more about whether you are rent stabilized? 

To learn about whether you are rent stabilized, say YES. To keep learning about repairs, say NO.

When you call 311,  list each and every bad condition in your apartment and the common areas of the building. An inspector should come within a week. If no inspector comes, just call again! 

Do you want to learn about how to find the results online after the inspection?

You can say: 

YES to learn more or NO if you already how to find your results.
Rent stabilized and rent controlled tenants can have their rent frozen or reduced due to poor conditions in their apartment. Would you like to learn more about rent freezes and rent reductions?

router.result_name: Find HPD violations online or go to LOC

actions.text:
Look at your first and most recent lease. If it says you are rent stabilized, that's a good sign you are protected. Do you want to learn how to ask the State if your landlord has registered your apartment as rent stabilized? 

You can say YES to order your State rent history or NO to keep learning about repairs.
That's okay! Not everyone wants to talk to lawyer. Would you like to hear about ways to figure out if you're rent stabilized yourself?
Type YES to learn more about whether you are rent stabilized or NO to continue to learn about ways to get repairs.
You can sue NYCHA in housing court by filing a case called an HP Action.
HP Actions are lawsuits tenants file against their landlord in housing court to obtain repairs.
Do you want to learn about how to start an HP Action?
You can say YES to learn more about HP Actions or NO to learn about other housing rights.
Here are some legal non-profits in your neighborhood:
For Legal Aid, call 212-426-3000 or visit: https://www.legalservicesnyc.org/our-program/manhattan
For Legal Services, NYC, call 917-661-4500 between 9:30-4:00 pm, or visit: https://www.legalservicesnyc.org/our-program/manhattan
You can also call 311 for legal referral!

While you wait to speak to a lawyer, would you like to learn more about getting repairs today? 

You can say YES or NO
A few days after the inspector visits your apartment, housing code violations will be posted on the HPD website.

Type your address into this website: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/hpd/about/hpd-online.page. Once your building information loads, look for the purple bar on the left side of the page and click, "all open violations."

Are you ready to take learn about other ways to get repairs? 

You can say: YES or NO

You can also file a lawsuit in housing court against your landlord for failure to make repairs. This kind of case is called an HP Action. Would you like to learn more about an HP Action?

You can say: YES or NO

router.result_name: Enter DHCR flow or return to repairs
Take to HPD inspection or end flow

actions.text:
Since your rent history will take a while to come, do you want to continue to learn about repairs?

You can write YES to learn about repairs or NO to learn about other your housing rights.
The Division of Homes and Community Renewal ("DHCR") can decide to freeze or reduce your rent for bad conditions.
DHCR is the agency that oversees rent stabilized and rent controlled apartments in New York State.
To learn how to file a complaint about your individual apartment type APARTMENT.
To learn how to file a complaint for the common areas in your apartment, type BUILDING.
If you are ready to take action against your landlord, you can use JustFix's letter of Complaint tool to write to letter to your landlord.
Click here to get started: https://app.justfix.nyc/en/loc/splash. JustFix will handle the printing and send it certified mail free of charge!

Do you you want learn about how to sue your landlord for repairs? 

You can say: YES to learn more lawsuits or NO to learn about other housing rights.
To file an HP Action, you can go to Manhattan Housing Court at  111 Centre Street, New York, NY 10013.
The clerk can be reached at  646-386-5750.
For more information on filing an HP Action, visit: http://www.courts.state.ny.us/courts/nyc/housing/startinghp.shtml

router.result_name: Learn about repairs after rent history or end flow

actions.text: To fill out a rent reduction for the common areas of your buildings like the entrance door, stairwells, elevator, or roof, visit: https://hcr.ny.gov/system/files/documents/2021/05/ra-84-fillable_0.pdf
You can ask your neighbors to sign on as well since poor conditions in the common areas affects everyone!

Do you also want to learn about making a complaint about your individual apartment?

You can say YES to learn more or NO to learn about a new housing topic.
Keep in mind that, the City will only send an independent inspector to an apartment or common area in NYCHA when you sue in housing court.
If you have already complained several times, an HP action may be your only option.

Do you want to reconsider filing an HP Action?

You can say: YES to learn how to file an HP or NO to lean about your other housing rights.

router.result_name: Learn more about HP private or end flow
Take to LOC or end flow
Learn about HP or end flow

actions.text: To file an HP Action, you can go to Manhattan Housing Court at  111 Centre Street, New York, NY 10013.
The clerk can be reached at  646-386-5750.
For more information on filing an HP Action, visit: http://www.courts.state.ny.us/courts/nyc/housing/startinghp.shtml

Did you know that rent stabilized and rent controlled tenants can apply to have their rent reduced or frozen due to bad conditions in their buildings and apartments?

You can say: YES to lean more or NO to learn about other housing topics.
To fill out a rent reduction with DHCR for your INDIVIDUAL APARTMENT, visit: https://hcr.ny.gov/system/files/documents/2021/05/ra-81-fillable_0.pdf

To fill out a rent reduction for the COMMON AREAS of your buildings like the entrance door, stairwells, elevator, or roof, visit: https://hcr.ny.gov/system/files/documents/2021/05/ra-84-fillable_0.pdf
You can ask your neighbors to sign on as well! There's power in group action!
To fill out a rent reduction with DHCR for your apartment, visit: https://hcr.ny.gov/system/files/documents/2021/05/ra-81-fillable_0.pdf

Do you also want to learn about making complaints about the common areas in your building (as opposed to your own apartment)?

You can say YES to learn more or NO to learn about a new housing topic.
That's okay! Not everyone wants to file a lawsuit against their landlord.
If you are rent stabilized or rent controlled, as another option, you can ask the State to freeze or decrease your rent due to bad conditions.

Do you want to learn more about rent reductions?

You can say: YES to learn more about rent reductions or NO to learn about another housing topic.

2c072dd3-36e5-4519-b6e1-7473e93df266.title: TODO: Support "goodbye"
2c072dd3-36e5-4519-b6e1-7473e93df266.body:
Currently this flow doesn't support the "goodbye" keyword.

Note also that if the user says "STOP" the message will actually be intercepted by Twilio, not the chatbot, and Twilio will prevent the bot from communicating with the user until they reply with "START". For more details see: https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223134027-Twilio-support-for-opt-out-keywords-SMS-STOP-filtering-

If this turns out to be hard, for now we may just want to avoid suggesting that the user can type "goodbye" at any point.

79a1cd5d-1767-49ec-97d8-827869aba9f6.title: TODO: Handle confusing input better
79a1cd5d-1767-49ec-97d8-827869aba9f6.body: Right now, if the user says something that isn't an understood response (e.g. replying to a yes/no question with "boop") we just repeat the question without mentioning that we didn't understand what the user said. It would be nice to do something more user-friendly.

6a4a3124-f251-4da6-aa78-68cbd5dfbf3e.title: This flow is based on a google diagram
6a4a3124-f251-4da6-aa78-68cbd5dfbf3e.body: To compare it with the original diagram, see: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1iEzkYXfe6-vezgYlIc6ouyeSEn0D0NOIARhrSmA9HiE/edit

85584080-d83f-45cc-b1ee-bb374eca6d55.title: New Note
85584080-d83f-45cc-b1ee-bb374eca6d55.body: TODO: Figure out why no Yes or No pops up betwen HP Action
